question: Question_02_(c)
statement:
Suppose the tangent line to the graph of \emph{y} = $f(x)$ at
\emph{x} = 1 is \emph{y} = 2\emph{x} + 1, and $f$(3) = 2.

(c) Let \emph{g}(\emph{x}) = 3$f$(4\emph{x} + 5). Given the information
from previous parts of this question, there is one number \emph{b} for
which both \emph{g}(\emph{b}) and \emph{g}'(\emph{b}) can be found. What
are \emph{b}, \emph{g}(\emph{b}) and \emph{g}'(\emph{b})?
